Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: A report has come in about a suspicious, unattended bag in one of the train cars.
Story: I was just about to take out my trash when I noticed the bins were only half-full. Mrs. Kim, my neighbor, always reminds everyone not to put out the bins unless they’re full, to avoid cluttering the sidewalk. I hesitated, trash bag in hand, thinking about her disapproving look last week when someone ignored the rule. My phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from the control center: a suspicious, unattended bag had been found on my train. As a subway operator, I’m expected to respond immediately, ensuring passenger safety and following strict protocols. My heart pounded. If I left the trash, Mrs. Kim would surely notice and probably complain. But if I delayed responding to the report, I’d be neglecting my duty to the passengers. I stood there, torn between the quiet expectations of my neighborhood and the urgent responsibility of my job, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
